prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 30-year-old man presented with several months of pain, tenderness, and swelling on the left side of his palate. On examination, the left palatine mucosa was diffusely swollen—most pronounced in the molar region—with poorly defined borders and increased pain on palpation. T2-weighted MRI demonstrated a high-signal-intensity lesion in that area. Panoramic radiography and CT scans of the maxilla and sinuses were unremarkable, and all left maxillary teeth appeared healthy. His medical and family histories were unremarkable, and he denied any history of trauma or inflammation in the head or neck. Empiric treatment with oral antibiotics and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs for 7 days produced no improvement. Based on the clinical and radiographic findings, a soft-tissue tumor was suspected, and an incisional biopsy was performed.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 27-year-old left-hand–dominant man presented with bilateral clicking and discomfort of several years’ duration, localized to the anterior aspects of both elbows and slowly worsening despite simple analgesia and physiotherapy. He reported intermittent paraesthesia in the forearms, particularly after physical activity. Symptoms were exacerbated by pull-ups and heavy lifting at work. He was otherwise healthy. On examination, both elbows had a full range of motion, with no instability or weakness. Grip and grind tests were negative bilaterally. There was no objective sensory disturbance, and Tinel’s sign was negative. The hook test for distal biceps rupture was negative, and provocative testing of the biceps produced no pain. While moving the left elbow, a palpable click over the lateral biceps tendon reduced with digital pressure. Plain radiographs and MRI of both elbows revealed no pathology. The decision was made to perform surgical exploration of the right elbow.

completion.content:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a subluxation of the bicep's long head tendon over the posterior humeral head. Risks of nonoperative treatment are long-term symptoms (pain and or restriction of movement, which may interfere with function); hesitancy that risks surgery without a therapeutic need, as the symptoms may have appeared to be nowhere in existence only a day before.In contrast, operative treatment is also painful initially, and there is a risk of the contracture/permanent weakness/immobility of the elbow, and the unnecessary complication of this rare yet significant procedure. Risks exist that are asymmetric, (that is, if the surgery is only performed only on one elbow). Risks exist if complications do occur, before, during or after the surgery, to both Elbow and Wrist as well as Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. Risks before include skin necrosis, leading to infection and/or limited movement/swelling. Risks during include pneumothorax, infection of the bloodstream, fluid (pulmonary oedema also ischemia). Risks after include arthritis/Ulnar nerve palsy with glove and stirrup symptomatology (carpal tunnel syndrome). Risks after surgery also include elbow stiffness and atrophy, wrist pain, and late need for re-operation. Risks may include pain, numbness, and shoulder problem, altered force transmission on the forearm musculature, and peipheral nerve damage and erosion of the surgical incision, in the form of trap door/shoulder lock development (a pathologic elevation of the humerus) that makes movements of the elbow able-to-passive or difficult. Risks of ungoliness of the residual tendon may occur. Risks includes longitudinal runs, knots and inability to use the arm, chronic pain, and gradual loss of strength.

During the summer of 1995, she worked as a lifeguard in Lake Ontario and was unable to voluntarily move her left arm downward or upward for an approximately 15-minute period. Physical therapy was unsuccessful and left arm mobility returned normally after seven months.

Since there is no apparent cause or evidence of a neurological cause for the injury, the most likely cause of the injury is trauma i.e. extreme shear force from the water or striking her head on the rear of the pool.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 75-year-old woman, gravida 2, postmenopausal for many years, presented with vaginal bleeding of one week’s duration. She had a history of hyperlipidemia managed medically. Laboratory studies showed a CA 19-9 level of 9.8 U/mL, a CA-125 level of 13.5 U/mL, and a serum glucose concentration of 118 mg/dL. Contrast-enhanced abdominal and pelvic computed tomography revealed a multiseptated cystic mass in the left adnexa, adherent to the left psoas muscle and adjacent small and large bowel loops, with a possibility of an underlying chronic inflammatory process or abscess. Under the impression of a possible mucinous cystadenoma, the patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 27-year-old man, 6 months after deceased-donor kidney transplantation for IgA nephropathy, presented with 3 days of high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, headache, and myalgia. His brother, a household contact, had been diagnosed with dengue fever. He was on mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus (trough 7 ng/ml), and steroids; graft function had nadir creatinine 0.8 mg/dl. He denied abdominal pain, dysuria, jaundice, arthralgia, rash, or neurologic symptoms. On exam he was dehydrated, hypotensive (90/60 mmHg), tachycardic, and otherwise unremarkable. Initial labs showed pancytopenia (hemoglobin 10.4 g/dl, WBC 2000/mm3, platelets 39 000/mm3), acute graft dysfunction (creatinine 2.1 mg/dl), hyponatremia (Na 127 mEq/L), and ECG with sinus tachycardia. Abdominal ultrasound revealed mild splenomegaly. Intravenous fluids stabilized his blood pressure; tacrolimus dose was reduced, mycophenolate was held, and stress-dose steroids were given. Dengue NS1 antigen was positive; tests for leptospirosis, malaria, and scrub typhus were negative, and blood and urine cultures were sterile. He was diagnosed with dengue fever. Over the next days, renal function and blood pressure normalized, but fever persisted, pancytopenia worsened, and hsCRP and D-dimer levels rose. He developed mucosal bleeding requiring platelet transfusion; serum ferritin was 26 250 ng/ml and LDH 665 U/L.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 75-year-old woman with treated hypertension and long-standing stable angina despite maximal medical therapy (bisoprolol 5 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, isosorbide mononitrate 40 mg twice daily) was referred for PCI of a chronic total occlusion (CTO) in the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). Baseline ECG showed sinus rhythm without Q waves, and transthoracic echocardiography revealed preserved LV systolic function with mild inferior hypokinesia. Coronary angiography confirmed a dominant RCA CTO (J-CTO score 1) and non-flow-limiting disease in the left system. 

The procedure was performed via dual access (right radial 6 Fr and right femoral 8 Fr). After crossing the occlusion with a Gaia 2nd wire and pre-dilating with a 2.5 × 15 mm balloon, extensive dissection occurred. Two overlapping drug-eluting stents (3.5 × 36 mm and 3.5 × 33 mm) were deployed, after which her blood pressure fell to 60/40 mmHg. Two additional overlapping stents were placed distally, but hypotension persisted, refractory to fluid boluses and intravenous phenylephrine boluses. The patient complained of dizziness and had elevated venous pressures. 

Pericardial tamponade was suspected; an urgent echocardiogram showed no pericardial effusion in the subcostal view. A careful review of the angiograms showed no evidence of coronary perforation or catheter-related dissection in the left system, and the ECG remained unchanged. Femoral angiography excluded access-site bleeding. Other considerations—nitrate effect, vagal reaction, and anaphylaxis—were deemed unlikely given the timing, vital signs, and lack of response to fluids, vasopressors, and antihistamines. With ongoing hypotension, an intra-aortic balloon pump was inserted, achieving a systolic pressure of 100 mmHg. Laboratory tests revealed a hemoglobin drop from 13.2 g/dL pre-procedure to 11 g/dL. To rule out a retroperitoneal bleed, an urgent CT scan was performed.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 27-year-old left-hand–dominant man presented with bilateral clicking and discomfort of several years’ duration, localized to the anterior aspects of both elbows and slowly worsening despite simple analgesia and physiotherapy. He reported intermittent paraesthesia in the forearms, particularly after physical activity. Symptoms were exacerbated by pull-ups and heavy lifting at work. He was otherwise healthy. On examination, both elbows had a full range of motion, with no instability or weakness. Grip and grind tests were negative bilaterally. There was no objective sensory disturbance, and Tinel’s sign was negative. The hook test for distal biceps rupture was negative, and provocative testing of the biceps produced no pain. While moving the left elbow, a palpable click over the lateral biceps tendon reduced with digital pressure. Plain radiographs and MRI of both elbows revealed no pathology. The decision was made to perform surgical exploration of the right elbow.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 75-year-old woman, gravida 2, postmenopausal for many years, presented with vaginal bleeding of one week’s duration. She had a history of hyperlipidemia managed medically. Laboratory studies showed a CA 19-9 level of 9.8 U/mL, a CA-125 level of 13.5 U/mL, and a serum glucose concentration of 118 mg/dL. Contrast-enhanced abdominal and pelvic computed tomography revealed a multiseptated cystic mass in the left adnexa, adherent to the left psoas muscle and adjacent small and large bowel loops, with a possibility of an underlying chronic inflammatory process or abscess. Under the impression of a possible mucinous cystadenoma, the patient underwent an exploratory laparotomy.

The radiologic imaging shows a multiseptated cystic mass in the left adnexa adherent to the left psoas muscle and adjacent small and large bowel loops with a possibility of an underlying chronic inflammatory process or abscess. An exploratory laparotomy is planned.</think>

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 27-year-old man, 6 months after deceased-donor kidney transplantation for IgA nephropathy, presented with 3 days of high-grade fever, retro-orbital pain, headache, and myalgia. His brother, a household contact, had been diagnosed with dengue fever. He was on mycophenolate mofetil, tacrolimus (trough 7 ng/ml), and steroids; graft function had nadir creatinine 0.8 mg/dl. He denied abdominal pain, dysuria, jaundice, arthralgia, rash, or neurologic symptoms. On exam he was dehydrated, hypotensive (90/60 mmHg), tachycardic, and otherwise unremarkable. Initial labs showed pancytopenia (hemoglobin 10.4 g/dl, WBC 2000/mm3, platelets 39 000/mm3), acute graft dysfunction (creatinine 2.1 mg/dl), hyponatremia (Na 127 mEq/L), and ECG with sinus tachycardia. Abdominal ultrasound revealed mild splenomegaly. Intravenous fluids stabilized his blood pressure; tacrolimus dose was reduced, mycophenolate was held, and stress-dose steroids were given. Dengue NS1 antigen was positive; tests for leptospirosis, malaria, and scrub typhus were negative, and blood and urine cultures were sterile. He was diagnosed with dengue fever. Over the next days, renal function and blood pressure normalized, but fever persisted, pancytopenia worsened, and hsCRP and D-dimer levels rose. He developed mucosal bleeding requiring platelet transfusion; serum ferritin was 26 250 ng/ml and LDH 665 U/L.

completion.content: He developed mucosal bleeding requiring platelet transfusion; serum ferritin was 26 250 ng/ml and LDH 665 U/L. Pulmonary bleeding was confirmed by bronchoscopy. His symptoms of fever of 3 weeks’ duration, intravascular microinfarcts noted on renal biopsy, recent haematoma formation, thrombocytosis, and recent organ transplantation developed dengue infection.

prompt.content: You are a biomedical reasoning model. You must think step-by-step and reason carefully about the following medical case before providing your diagnosis. You should enclose your thoughts and reasoning inside <think> </think> tags, and then provide your final diagnosis concisely.

A 75-year-old woman with treated hypertension and long-standing stable angina despite maximal medical therapy (bisoprolol 5 mg daily, amlodipine 5 mg daily, isosorbide mononitrate 40 mg twice daily) was referred for PCI of a chronic total occlusion (CTO) in the proximal right coronary artery (RCA). Baseline ECG showed sinus rhythm without Q waves, and transthoracic echocardiography revealed preserved LV systolic function with mild inferior hypokinesia. Coronary angiography confirmed a dominant RCA CTO (J-CTO score 1) and non-flow-limiting disease in the left system. 

The procedure was performed via dual access (right radial 6 Fr and right femoral 8 Fr). After crossing the occlusion with a Gaia 2nd wire and pre-dilating with a 2.5 × 15 mm balloon, extensive dissection occurred. Two overlapping drug-eluting stents (3.5 × 36 mm and 3.5 × 33 mm) were deployed, after which her blood pressure fell to 60/40 mmHg. Two additional overlapping stents were placed distally, but hypotension persisted, refractory to fluid boluses and intravenous phenylephrine boluses. The patient complained of dizziness and had elevated venous pressures. 

Pericardial tamponade was suspected; an urgent echocardiogram showed no pericardial effusion in the subcostal view. A careful review of the angiograms showed no evidence of coronary perforation or catheter-related dissection in the left system, and the ECG remained unchanged. Femoral angiography excluded access-site bleeding. Other considerations—nitrate effect, vagal reaction, and anaphylaxis—were deemed unlikely given the timing, vital signs, and lack of response to fluids, vasopressors, and antihistamines. With ongoing hypotension, an intra-aortic balloon pump was inserted, achieving a systolic pressure of 100 mmHg. Laboratory tests revealed a hemoglobin drop from 13.2 g/dL pre-procedure to 11 g/dL. To rule out a retroperitoneal bleed, an urgent CT scan was performed.
